banner.mainContent: Don't miss out! Be one of the first to see our powerful new talks.

fields.title: TED Tech Jun 12 Tablet Portrait Talks (3)
TED Tech Jun 12 Tablet Landscape Talks (5)

videoData.title: How we'll find life on other planets
videoData.socialTitle: How we'll find life on other planets

recommendations.blurb: Explore planets outside of our Solar System with these resources curated by Aomawa Shields.

recItems.blurb: Written for a general audience, this book explores what makes a planet habitable, including the evolution of our planet and the history and fate of other planets in the Solar System, such as Venus and Mars. Finally, prospects for life on worlds outside of the Solar System are explored, in a very accessible way for the reader.
recItems.headline: *How to Find a Habitable Planet*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: Nice, introductory approach to what governs planetary climate — the incoming energy from the host star and the outgoing radiation from the planet in response to that incoming energy. Any imbalance due to the planets response results in a change in temperature. But how does that happen? Read this book to find out.
recItems.headline: *Elementary Climate Physics*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
F. W. Taylor 
Oxford University Press, 2005

recItems.blurb: The "Bible" of exoplanet climatology. Written by one of my mentors and a pioneer in the field of using climate models and the principles of Earth's climate to explore how planets orbiting stars achieve global energy balance, this book is upper-level to be sure. If you want to go MUCH more in depth on the subject of how we are trying to figure out what the climates of exoplanets might be like, this book is for you.
recItems.headline: *Principles of Planetary Climate*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Raymond T. Pierrehumbert
Cambridge University Press, 2011

recItems.blurb: A book that's very close to my scientific heart, focusing in on the habitability of planets orbiting a very specific class of stars — red dwarf stars. These stars are the most numerous stars in the galaxy (70 percent of all stars are red, or "M-dwarf" stars,) so they offer us the best chances of finding life through sheer numbers alone. But when it comes to whether life might actually be able to survive on a planet orbiting a red dwarf star, it's a bit more complicated. This book is the only book I know of that deals with this question exclusively. Be aware, though, that the book is a bit out of date now. There has been a lot of research done (including by yours truly) to shed new light on the prospects for life on planets orbiting these cool, dark stars.
recItems.headline: *Under a Crimson Sun: Prospects for Life in a Red Dwarf System*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: I'm a writer, and I meditate. Natalie Goldberg taught me how to do both. This is her first book, and this year marks the 30th anniversary of its publication. Her teaching has informed me as a writer of both creative non-fiction, poetry, and indeed, academic writing as well.
recItems.headline: *Writing Down the Bones: Freeing the Writer Within*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: And this is how Natalie organizes the workshops she taught in Taos, NM for decades. I attended many of these workshops, and I still go when I can.
recItems.headline: *The True Secret of Writing: Connecting Life with Language*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.headline: "The Best Bet for Alien Life May Be in Planetary Systems Very Different From Ours"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: Here's a talk that I recently gave on as part of a session entitled "The Climate of Short-Period Planets" at the Kavli Frontiers of Sciences Symposium in November, 2015. If you want to go more in-depth than my TED Talk went, listen to this 20-min talk.
recItems.headline: The Climate and Habitability of M-dwarf Planets
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: Visit this great place to go to learn more about exoplanets -- the latest discoveries, missions, and results.
recItems.headline: Expolanet Travel Bureau
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: This website is devoted to NASA's Kepler Mission and the planets it has found. The press releases here are great for short, quick info on what's been discovered, and what it means for the field.
recItems.headline: Kepler: A Search for Habitable Planets
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: This is my favorite TED talk of all time. Power poses are part of my preparation process before any talk I give (including my TED talk!).
recItems.headline: Amy Cuddy: Your body language shapes who you are
recItems.label: WATCH

nodes.whoTheyAre: Aomawa Shields studies the climate and habitability of planets outside of the Solar System.
nodes.whyListen:
Dr. Aomawa Shields received her PhD in Astronomy and Astrobiology from the University of Washington in 2014. She also received an MFA in Acting from UCLA in 2001, and a Bachelor's degree in Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences from MIT in 1997. She is currently an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellow, a UC President's Postdoctoral Program Fellow, and a 2015 TED Fellow at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics.

Dr. Shields is the founder of Rising Stargirls, an organization dedicated to encouraging girls of all colors and backgrounds to explore and discover the universe using theater, writing, and visual art. She uses her theater and writing background to communicate science to the public in engaging, innovative ways.

videoData.description: Astronomer Aomawa Shields searches for clues that life might exist elsewhere in the universe by examining the atmospheres of distant exoplanets. When she isn't exploring the heavens, the classically trained actor (and TED Fellow) looks for ways to engage young women in the sciences using theater, writing and visual art. "Maybe one day they'll join the ranks of astronomers who are full of contradictions," she says, "and use their backgrounds to discover, once and for all, that we are truly not alone in the universe."
videoData.socialDescription: Astronomer Aomawa Shields searches for clues that life might exist elsewhere in the universe by examining the atmospheres of distant exoplanets. When she isn't exploring the heavens, the classically trained actor (and TED Fellow) looks for ways to engage young women in the sciences using theater, writing and visual art. "Maybe one day they'll join the ranks of astronomers who are full of contradictions," she says, "and use their backgrounds to discover, once and for all, that we are truly not alone in the universe."

cues.text:
我一直在尋找宇宙中
另一顆存在生命的行星。
我無法通過肉眼，

甚至也無法借助我們現有的
最先進的望遠鏡觀測到這顆行星。
但我知道這顆行星是存在的。
而理解自然界中發生的一些矛盾或衝突，
則將會幫助我們尋找到這顆行星。
在我們地球上，
但凡有水的地方，就會存在生命。

因此，我們所要尋找的就是
按照某個適當的距離，
圍繞著恆星旋轉的那種行星。
這適當的距離，就是圖上藍色區域部分，

標示了行星與不同溫度恆星
之間的適當距離，

行星的溫度就足夠溫暖，
從而能使水源在它們的表面流動起來
就像湖泊和海洋，
生命就可能存活於這些水中。

一些天文學家
便把他們的目光及精力集中在

尋找這種與恆星有
維持適當距離的行星研究上。

而我的工作則是基於
這些天文學家們的研究結果而展開的。

我通過構建模型來模擬
太陽系以外的行星上可能出現的氣候。
我這項工作之所以重要，
是因為，除了距離，

還有其他很多因素會決定
一個行星是否能夠維繫生命的存在。
拿金星舉例來說。

金星這個名字來源於古羅馬
的愛神、美神維納斯，
因為它在天空中看上去輕盈且柔美。

但宇宙飛船的數據卻揭示了
金星另一個不同的故事。
金星地表溫度接近900華氏度，
也就是500攝氏度。
那樣的高溫足以熔化金屬鉛。

造成高溫的原因不是
金星與太陽之間的距離近，
而是金星自身厚重的大氣層。

它造成了類似施打了
類固醇的溫室效應，

這大氣層困住了來自太陽的熱量
並烘烤著行星表面，

這一事實完全違背了
（人們對於金星）最初的認識。
這些來自我們太陽系的教訓告訴我們，
行星的大氣層對它的氣候

以及它是否可能維繫生命
有著決定性的作用。

我們無從知道這些行星
究竟有什麼樣的大氣層。

因為，相對於恆星而言，
這些行星不僅太小還昏暗不清，
而且這些行星距離我們非常遙遠。

比如，距離我們最近的一顆
可能存在地表水的行星，
它叫“格利澤667 CC”。

多棒的一個名字，
對，跟電話號碼一樣的有趣的名字。
這顆行星距離我們23光年，

那也就是100萬億英里
（約161萬億千米）以外。

對這樣一顆繞行與某顆恆星的
系外行星而言，
測量它的大氣層成分非常困難。

這就像是試圖去看清楚
一隻飛過車燈果蠅一樣。

那麼，現在試想一下，
當那輛車離你有100萬億英里那麼遠，

而妳還想知道那隻飛過（車燈前）的果蠅
是什麼精確的顏色。
因此，我採用電腦模型

去計算哪樣的行星大氣層
可能產生出一種適宜的氣候。

這種適宜的氣候
可以保證水源和生命的存在。

這是來自於一位藝術家的關於（行星）
“卡普勒62F”的一個概念（作品），
用地球作為參照。
這顆行星距離地球有1200光年，
並且只有比地球大40%。

我們這項得到美國國家科學基金會資助
的研究發現這顆行星可能足夠溫暖
從而存在水源，

在很多種類型的大氣層和很多
不同方向的運行軌道的情形下都是這樣。

因此，我希望未來的望遠鏡
可以跟蹤這顆行星，
看看能不能發現生命的跡象。

行星表面上存在的冰
對於氣候也有重要的影響。

冰會吸收光譜中波長
更長、更紅的那些光，
而反射回去波長相對較短、更藍的光。

照片上的冰山之所以會顯得那麼藍
正是因為這個原因。

太陽光中更紅的光
會在穿透冰塊的過程中被（冰塊）吸收，
只有藍光才能真正穿透到達冰塊底部。

這樣一來，它（藍光）就會反射出來，
反射到我們的眼睛裡，
我們便因此看到了藍色的冰。

我的模型顯示，
圍繞溫度較冷的恆星旋轉的行星

會實際上比那些圍繞
溫度較高的恆星旋轉的行星溫度更高。
另外還有一個矛盾。

那就是，冰會吸收從溫度較低的恆星上
發射出來的波長較長光；

而這些（被吸收的）光，這些能量，
會使冰本身的溫度升高。

借助氣象模型去探索
這些矛盾如何影響行星上的氣候

對於尋找（地球以外的）生命
有至關重要的意義。

這也解釋了為什麼這
（借助模型尋找生命的研究方法）
成為了我的研究專長。
我是一名非裔美國女性天文學工作者，
同時還是一名接受過正統訓練的演員，
我愛化妝， 愛讀時尚雜誌。

所以，我特別適合去欣賞
和領悟自然中的矛盾。
（笑聲）
（鼓掌）

而且認識到這些矛盾
可以引領我們尋找
存在於另一顆行星的生命。
我的一個組織名為Rising Stargirls。

它利用劇院、文字著作和視覺藝術去教
那些有色種族的中學女生天文學知識。

這裡還有另一個矛盾——
科學和藝術並不是經常同時出現的。

但是，將這兩者結合起來是可以幫助
這些女孩們全身心地投入到
她們的所學中去的。
也許某一天，她們會（如我這般）自身充滿矛盾，而躋身到天文學者的隊伍中去。
而憑藉她們自己的背景

去發現原來我們真的
不是浩瀚宇宙中唯一的生命。
謝謝。
（鼓掌）

footnotes.annotation: How do I know that it's there (or rather, believe strongly that it's there)? Because, as is pointed out in the movie *Contact* (and the book I think, too, although it's been a long time since I've read it), "The universe is a pretty big place. If it's just us, seems like an awful waste of space."
The official name of the field I'm in is "exoplanet climatology."

I once participated in a workshop called "Revisiting the Habitable Zone." We all sat in a few rooms for several days hashing out all of the factors that can affect a planet's ability to maintain liquid water on its surface. The figure we made using all of these factors looked like a huge spider's web. There are so many influences. Both stellar and planetary environments play a role.
Without an atmosphere, the average surface temperature on the Earth would be 255 K. That's -18 degrees Celsius, 0 degrees Fahrenheit. An atmosphere is a really important thing!

See [kepler.nasa.gov](http://kepler.nasa.gov/) for info on the mission that found this planet. Also, [this press release.](http://kepler.nasa.gov/news/nasakeplernews/index.cfm?FuseAction=ShowNews&NewsID=243)
I have a paper submitted for publication on these results. Stay tuned!

Here are two papers detailing this phenomenon, and its implications for climate: 
[The Effect of Host Star Spectral Energy Distribution and Ice-Albedo Feedback on the Climate of Extrasolar Planets](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013AsBio..13..715S)
[Spectrum-driven Planetary Deglaciation due to Increases in Stellar Luminosity](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2014ApJ...785L...9S)

And here's a press article on this work: ["A warmer planetary haven around cool stars, as ice warms rather than cools"](http://www.washington.edu/news/2013/07/18/a-warmer-planetary-haven-around-cool-stars-as-ice-warms-rather-than-cools/)

You can also download the PDFs directly from my website: [variablestargirl.com/publications](http://variablestargirl.com/publications/)
I was even in a film that went to Sundance ([*Nine Lives*](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0420015/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm)) which was voted one of Ebert and Roeper's "Top Ten Films of 2005."
This is one of my favorite fashion mags — [Glamour.com](http://www.glamour.com/). And as far as make-up goes, I buy a lot of Bobbi Brown and Lancôme, though I buy across other lines as well.

Visit [risingstargirls.org](http://www.risingstargirls.org/) for more info. Also, see our [article in *Education Week*](http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/curriculum/2015/03/nsf_fellow_pairs_art_astronomy.html).

And on the [Women in Astronomy Blog](http://womeninastronomy.blogspot.com/2015/02/rising-stargirls-girls-of-all-colors.html).

And for more on the importance of raising self-esteem in middle-school girls, see [this article from the NYU Child Study Center.](http://www.education.com/reference/article/Ref_Mirror_Mirror_Wall/))
